A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions have not been answered by others who may have had similar experiences. For example, some people may not have had the opportunity to attend school, while others may have attended school regularly. The answers given will vary depending on the individual's experiences.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions have will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

1. Your full name: Nicholas Gulstine

2. Your address: Farwell Lake, Sask.

3. Date: Dec. 22nd / 1954

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): No idea.

5. What was your father's name and occupation? L. N. Gulstine, farmer.

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): April, 1903.

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Minneota, U.S.A., 1892 - 1903.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.): Full grown.

9. What were your reasons for coming West? Adventure, and a government bounty.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?):

From R.R. and Government information. From the "Great West" and "Dominion" such as the U.S.A. papers, and in Canadian newspapers.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?): From R.R. and government information, such as the "Great West" and "Government booklet".
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Not much.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? Just myself and a brother.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Rail Road.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way; meetings with Indians; adventures on the journey; accidents or other excitements; etc.). Worth mentioning.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? At a ranch and trading post.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? On Traps 32, Rg 11, 2nd M.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. On Traps 33, Rg 11, 2nd M.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came? Trapping, hunting, fishing and working.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
